### Disease example: **Measles**  
*(One of the clearest “near‑elimination” stories linked to routine childhood vaccination)*  

| **What measles is** | Highly contagious viral infection (R₀ ≈ 12‑18).  In un‑vaccinated children it can cause pneumonia, encephalitis, permanent brain damage, and death. The case‑fatality rate in low‑resource settings can be 1‑2 % (up to 10 % in malnourished infants). |
|---------------------|---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|

---

## 1.  How measles looked before the vaccine

| Year | Global reported cases* | Global deaths* | U.S. annual cases (peak) |
|------|------------------------|----------------|--------------------------|
| 1960 | ≈ 12 million | ≈ 600 000 | ~400 000 (≈ 1 case per 800 people) |
| 1970 | ≈ 11 million | ≈ 500 000 | ~400 000 |
| 1980 | ≈ 7 million | ≈ 430 000 | ~300 000 |
| 1990 | ≈ 5 million | ≈ 350 000 | ~30 000 (after introduction of the two‑dose schedule in the U.S.) |

\*Numbers are from WHO/UNICEF historical surveillance reports. Reporting was less complete before the 1990s, so the true burden was probably higher.

### Key points
* Measles was **endemic** in every continent; most children were infected by age 5.  
* Large outbreaks could overwhelm hospitals and cause secondary complications (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media, diarrhoea).  
* The disease caused **significant mortality**—especially in low‑income countries where malnutrition and vitamin‑A deficiency were common.

---

## 2.  The vaccine rollout

| Milestone | What happened | Impact on coverage |
|-----------|----------------|--------------------|
| **1963** – First licensed **live‑attenuated measles vaccine** (single‑dose) | Used initially in high‑risk groups. | < 10 % of world‑wide infants. |
| **1970s–1980s** – Introduction of **MMR (measles‑mumps‑rubella)** in many high‑income countries | One dose given at 12‑15 months; later a second dose added (4‑6 yr) to catch primary‑vaccine failures. | By 1990, > 90 % coverage in the U.S., Western Europe, Japan, Australia. |
| **1990s** – Global **WHO/UNICEF measles‑vaccination initiative** | Goal: ≥ 90 % coverage of **two doses** worldwide. | Coverage rose from ~ 45 % (1990) to > 80 % (2010). |
| **2000** – **Measles‑Rubella Initiative** (Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation, CDC, UNICEF, WHO, others) | Massive funding, supplemental immunisation activities (SIAs) targeting children 9 months‑14 years every 2‑4 years in high‑burden regions. | Accelerated decline in incidence. |

---

## 3.  What the numbers look like **today** (2024)

|--------|----------------------|------|------|------------------------|
| **Global reported measles cases** | ~ 5 million | ~ 2 million | ~ 1 million | **≈ 7 million** (increase due to COVID‑19 disruptions) |
| **Global deaths** | ~ 350 000 | ~ 140 000 | ~ 100 000 | **≈ 140 000** (still higher than 2010) |
